posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone, our team is somewhat inexperienced when it comes to making controllable arms. We are experiencing a lot of backlash right now with our setup of a maxplanetary gearbox + 90 degree gearbox + chain onto a 1/2 in hexbar which pivots our arm. Moreover, our arm is very bouncy (if we are still and then I apply a force onto the arm it bounces with a large amplitude).

We are wondering if there are any quick fixes that wouldn’t require a complete redesign?

We are considering increasing the size of the sprocket that directly mounts onto the hex, or removing our chain altogether and putting the motor with a 90 degree gearbox directly onto the hex. We are also thinking about decreasing the length of the hex between the pivot point of the arm and the motor.

Any ideas would be greatly appreciated

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked:
Sounds like you have very underdamped PID .

What control scheme do you have in place? ArmFeedforward? TrapezoidalPID? How much backlash? How many motor revs to turn arm 360 degrees? How much arm travel do you need?

posts.name: Ryan Swanson
posts.cooked:
GronkBaby:

maxplanetary gearbox + 90 degree gearbox + chain onto a 1/2 in hexbar which pivots our arm

This sounds like a mechanical backlash stackup. Planetary gearboxes have some backlash, MAX90 gearboxes have more backlash, and hex shaft has some backlash… chain can introduce backlash if it isn’t super tight.

Planetary backlash: pretty much need to live with it without a big redesign

MAX90 backlash: I would try designing this out of the system if possible

Chain backlash: use an inline turnbuckle or external chain tensioner to ensure your chain is extremely tight

Hex shaft: you can shim hex shaft to remove quite a bit of backlash but an even better solution would be switching to MAX Spline if your design allows

A stackup of many small sources of backlash can easily result in 15 degrees or more at the arm.

Some pictures would be helpful to provide more specific recommendations.

posts.name: Atley Carman
posts.cooked: The biggest thing to try and reduce backlash, especially as the season goes on, is to try to avoid having your pivot driven by a hex interface. These tend to have a couple degrees of backlash, which add up quickly with a long arm. If possible I would recommend finding a way to either bolt the sprocket driving the arm directly to the arm, or switch to another type of axle, like maxspline. A larger top sprocket can help too, but I believe that the hex interface is your biggest source of backlash. If you have to run with hex shaft, definitely shim it, and check it fairly frequently for any twisting.

posts.name: Datis Reyhani
posts.cooked:
All the points mentioned above are great! Another way of reducing backlash in hex shaft joints is by pinning them all the way through - either cotter pins or bolts will do!

You could also probably do with a higher ratio on the MaxPlanetary gearbox (depending on what you’re running on at the moment), which would improve the holding torque your motors are providing.

And to echo Ryan, pictures or CAD would also be helpful

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Mechanical fixes discussed above are the right solution to this problem. Over time, backlash will only get worse and destroy your parts, costing you both matches and money.

However, during the time you’re stuck with backlash, using trapezoidal motion profiles helps immensely with reducing system wear and improving consistency and control. The quickest and easiest code fix code fix is to drop to a ProfiledPID , and start fiddling with values until performance is adequate, and crunchyness is minimized.

A constrained, and relatively low acceleration will reduce the forces applied to the system while the hardware gets patched up. And then once backlash is removed… you can crank those numbers up for better performance.

link_counts.title: Combining Motion Profiling and PID Control with ProfiledPIDController — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
For the Max90’s and the hex shaft and sprockets using shim tape to reduce the play (backlash) in the hex interfaces is one of the simplest things you can do.

4414 describes the procedure pretty well here. Team 4414 | HighTide | 2023 Robot: Tsunami - #231 by jjsessa

We do this for all our hex gears, sprockets, and the max90 input and output (sometimes the shims don’t fit).

Also post a photo of your mechanism there may be other sources of backlash such as parts flexing, or too little tension in the chain, etc.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
AllenGregoryIV:

shim tape

Usual caveats about shim tape apply: it is basically a razor blade. Use gloves… You will be lulled into a false sense of security the first time you use it and then cut the snot out of your fingers on the second gear.

Ok, I’ve said my bit.

Is this a live hex arm? If so, this is the worst problem by far and I would try to switch to a zombie axle or deadaxle as live hex is susceptible to torsional deflection which sucks a ton. 1/2hex is just not stiff, so even if there was 0 backlash, you would get a ton of torsional deflection. Maxspline live or deadaxle, or round pipe deadaxle are significantly stiffer and will help a lot.

I would also try to eliminate as many hex/hex interfaces as possible. Screwing chain directly into the arm or using a clamping mount will entirely eliminate backlash. Shim tape can help, but eliminating the problematic interface helps more.

Depending on when your first or second event is, a custom gearbox can be used to have much less backlash than a maxplanetary. We’re late into build season tho, so this might not be an option.

Is it also possible to post a video of the problematic arm?

Depending on when your first or second event is, a custom gearbox can be used to have much less backlash than a maxplanetary.

This is the answer, right here. Not all teams have the resources to build them but a custom gearbox with 20DP gears allows  you to reduce the backlash down to absolutely minimum levels - especially with shim tape on your intermediate gearbox stages. If you do have the ability to build one, doing so with a long arm is a borderline necessity.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 2930 Alumnus; Big Sky Robotics Ri3D Club President

posts.name: Andy Mundell
posts.cooked:
All the stuff above sound great. Another BIG thing is the location of your feedback sensor.

Are you using the built in motor encoder, or do you have an external encoder somewhere else. It’s hard to control a mechanism you don’t know the precise location of, and with lots of backlash, the difference between the expected location from a motor encoder and the actual location can be substantially different.

Try to mount a feedback device directly onto the arm itself, or at least as close as you can. This will make controlling the precise location of the arm much easier.

posts.name: ben gates
posts.cooked: To build off of Ryan here you can go even further to reduce backlash through a dead axle with a face-bolted sprocket

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: I have seen, in multiple threads, several recommendations to shim hex to reduce/eliminate  backlash. So, the question is: What materials are recommended to use as a shim?
There’s a product specifically for this: shim tape .

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: Excellent,  thanks. Next question(s): what width is preferred, and, what is the preferred method of applying it, wrap the shaft, apply to each face, or something  else?
Apply to opposing faces, the number of faces you need to apply shims to depends on how bad the tolerances are.

posts.name: Annalie
posts.cooked: When it comes to arms you need to look at something called rotational stiffness. Rotational stifness is basically how stiff the arm is with its natural frequency. If the natrual frequency of the arm is in the 1 to 2 hertz range then thats the root of the oslotaion you really want to aim in the 5 to 7 hz range if its a single jointed arm but if its double jointed then aim for the 4 to 5hz range. My team had the same problem in 2023 with our double jointed arm and we even used a custom gearbox. In order to stiffen the arm,  Since your using chain your going to want to change it to No.35 if its no 25H chain because its way stiffer. Also custom gearbox and using green loctite or loctite 380 will also get you the same reslut as shim tape but its more permanite solution and will require a heat gun or blowtorch to get off. If your unsure still id recomend looking at 971 debrif on thier 2023 arm design and it will go over rotaion stifnees and what materials would improve it. I hope this helps

It looks like most of your other questions were addressed, but with regards to tape width: the faces of 1/2" hex shaft are about 0.289" each, so 1/4" tape will let you neatly shim one face at a time if the tolerances are pretty close, and 1/2" tape will let you shim two adjacent faces with one piece if the tolerances are pretty sloppy.

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone, thank you so much for the help. I will upload some pics of the arm today.

We tried using a bigger sprocket and as predicted, it pretty much divided our rotational backlash by the ratio of the teeth between the sprockets.

Out of the mentioned fixes, I’m leaning towards shim tape, removing the 90 degree gearbox (if necessary), and replacing the chain with a stiffer one. We have an absolute encoder and will be using it for feedback. We will do motion profiling for smoother travel.

These seem like the easiest changes to make before our week 1 event.

As for afterwards, if we don’t completely remove our arm in favor of a different design, we will most likely remove the live hex. I keep seeing deadaxle everywhere, but I’m not sure what it means.

Another question, can shim tape be used on a hex interface in a printed pulley? Can it be used on bearings on hex? Is it good for all hex interfaces?

Are there any other easy ways to improve stiffness (that don’t involve redesign like using a custom gearbox)?

I would avoid printed pulleys. They are extremely not stiff and wear fast, further exaggerating the problem of live hex, which is already incredibly bad and likely the #1 contributor to your stiffness issues. Using shim tape on them is rather pointless if they are under any load, as the next match, they would already have worn.

Deadaxle is where the shaft remain fixed and the arm rotates around the shaft. In this setup, the shaft transmits 0 torque and therefore has no torsional deflection. Zombie axle is similar, but the shaft isn’t prevented from rotating, it just transmits 0 torque. Swapping to a zombie axle should be easy, as you just need to bolt the sprocket to the arm and now you avoid most of the hex shaft issues. I would suggest making this a very high priority, as no amount of driver skill or software can work around a robot that doesn’t do what it is told to do.
